title: scots-castle-owner-told-off-by-watchdog-over-unfair-raffle-to-get-rid-of-property
story: Susan DeVere set up the contest after her attempts to sell Orchardton Castle, near Auchencairn, Kirkcudbrightshire, failed.Built in the s, the -bedroom property had been valued at between pound. million and pound. million and comes with five acres of land and views across the Solway Firth.Tickets for the raffle, launched on Facebook and the winacastle website, cost pound and the winner was promised the opportunity to ldquowin the whole building freehold.However the raffle failed to generate enough ticket sales and the prize was changed to cash giveaways of pound,, pound, and pound,, which were handed out in June last year.One person complained to the Advertising Standards Authoritythat the raffle had been administered unfairly because the prize had been changed to a cash amount.Mrs DeVere told the ASA that all property competitions were run in the same way and that the castle could not be awardedthere were not enough entries received to clear the mortgage.She said it was made clear from the beginning thatnot enough entries were received, the property would not be awarded and a cash prize would be offered instead.Mrs DeVere added that after the prize draw had taken place the winner was offered a share of the property and a chance to run a business there had they wanted to, which was a goodwill offer unconnected to the competition. The winner chose to accept the cash prize.The ASA said the complainant had entered the promotion in the hope of winning the castle.It said: ldquoWe understood that at the end of the competition three cash prizes were awarded at the value of pound,, pound, and pound, instead of the advertised prize, because the minimum number of entries had not been reached, and that the advertiser had offered the winner a share of the property.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoHowever, we considered that a share of the property or any cash alternative that was less than the value of the property, were not reasonable equivalents to the prize as advertised.ldquoBecause neither the advertised prize nor a reasonable alternative had been awarded, we concluded that the promotion had not been administered fairly and was in breach of the code.Mrs DeVere said in a statement: ldquoIt is fair enough to challenge a competition or any unfairness and it should have taken the ASA a heartbeat to look at our site and see that from the beginning everything was spelled out, including that a cash prize to the value of tickets . Examples were givenwould happenenough entries were not received.She said she intends to appeal the ruling.

title: pro-independence-blogger-loses-25k-defamation-case-against-kezia-dugdale
story: The former ScottishLabourleader was the subject of a legal action by Stuart Campbell, who runs the website Wings OverScotland, after she accused him of writing ldquohomophobic tweets.After a three-day hearing atEdinburghSherf Court, Sherf Nigel Ross has now issued a written judgement ruling Ms Dugdale will not have to pay damages.He found that although she was incorrect to imply Mr Campbell was a homophobe in her Daily Record column, the article was covered by the defence of fair comment.: Nicola Sturgeon - Scotland will be independent in five yearsThe row centred on a tweet Mr Campbell, , sent in March .He wrote that the Scottish Secretary David Mundellrsquos son, the ToryMSP Oliver Mundell, was ldquothe sort of public speaker that makes you wish his dad had embraced his homosexuality sooner".David Mundell came out as gay in  and has described it as ldquoone of the most dficult things he has ever done.Writing in her Daily Record column a few days later, Ms Dugdale said she was ldquoshocked and appalled to see a pro-independence bloggers homophobic tweets, and accused Wings Over Scotland of spouting "hatred and homophobia towards others".: Tony Blair - Scotland might have been independent now it hadnt been for devolutionMr Campbell denied he is homophobic and insisted her comments were defamatory.He previously told the court he was ldquoabsolutely horried to be accused of making homophobic remarks, and had consistently supported gay rights.He called the claims "self-evidently ludicrous" and argued anyone who interpreted his remark in such a way was either dishonest or stupid ndash including gay politicians.Sherf Ross said: ldquoDespite incorrectly implying that Mr Campbell is homophobic, her article is protected under the principle of fair comment.For all your breaking Glasgow news, click here, or head to our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram pagesldquoShe is not liable to pay damages to Mr Campbell.He found Mr Campbell does not hold homophobic beliefs or feelings, and his tweet was intended as an "insulting jibe" about Oliver Mundell.The judge said Ms Dugdales article was "accordingly defamatory of the pursuer", as it implied Mr Campbellis homophobic.However, he ruled that the MSPs comments were fair "because the content of the tweet formed a basis of fact for a rational belief that it was derogatory about homosexual people".He said Mr Campbell had suffered "no quantiable financial or other loss as a result of the article", and suffered no loss of influence."The value of any loss would have been quantied at pound," he added.

title: Iain Macwhirter  As May goes down for the third time  the road to Brexit just got a whole lot longer
story: The Prime Minister has behaved asshe had a thumping Commons majority when in fact she is a minority leader of an unstable coalition. Even after the Damascene conversion of arch-Brexiter Jacob Rees-Mogg, who used to described her deal as ldquovassalage, her final attempt to get a stripped-down Withdrawal Agreement through Parliament failed on Friday by a substantial majority. You have to give May full marks for her consistency: everything she touches turns to dust, even her own resignation.But thatrsquos by the by. As everyone has been saying: we are where we are. And where we are is extremely uncomfortable. Brexiters are gearing up to have a belly laugh at the opposition MPs, who will do their best throughout the coming week to find a compromise. Who do they think they are  Playing at being a provisional government  ldquoItrsquos like allowing the whelk stall to be run by the whelks, according to the Tory MP Sir Bill Cash. Butno-one  is able to run the eponymous stall, then all power to the whelks.Last weekrsquos indicative votes suggested that MPs are broadly in favour of a Brexit that keeps Britain in the EUrsquos economic loop while leaving the political institutions. Curiously, the SNP, who have been arguing for soft Brexit in two white papers and an election manesto, decided not to vote for the ious options, even the Norway model that they have long extolled. The SNP did, however, vote for the proposal from the Labour MP Margaret Beckett for a confirmatory ballot, and this option got the largest number of votes, much to everyonersquos surprise. This must be a serious possibility now that Parliament has failed to resolve the Brexit conundrum.However, this is not a Peoplersquos Vote as some have styled it. A confirmatory vote is not a rerun of the  referendum, but strictly a chance for voters to give their views on whatever deal Parliament agrees . The Kyle Wilson Amendment originally envisaged putting the Prime Ministerrsquos deal to a popular vote, assuming it was passed by Parliament. However, this confirmatory referendum might be dficult to schedule because it could collide with three other elections: a Tory leadership election, the European elections and a General Election. Brenda from Bristol will be in despair.EvenMPs fail to come up with a working compromise, they can still block a no-deal Brexit. The majority against leaving the EU without a deal is overwhelming. This means May, or her successor, will have to go cap-in-hand to Brussels in the next few days and request another, longer delay to Article . This would mean Britain participating in the European elections in May, which excites the Independent Group of Tory and Labour rebels, but is looked upon with dread by the main parties. Brussels too is worried about populist contagion spreading to other EU countries like Italy, but they are legally bound to make British participation a condition of any further extension to AVoter wrath, particularly in Labourrsquos leave constituencies, could lead to a dramatic revival of Nigel Faragersquos Ukip, or worse. The Svengali behind the  Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, is gearing up for the fight and reportedly suggesting a new party to fight for the right to leave. ldquoTell them again is the favoured slogan. The European elections might themselves turn into a kind of second referendum on Brexit.The Tories will presumably have a new leader by then, since Theresa May will surely go now there is to be the long extension she has resolutely opposed. Mind you, it is impossible to guess the Prime Ministerrsquos thought processes. She said she would goher withdrawal deal passed on Friday. But her gambit didnrsquot work. Even the opportunity to dispense with Mayrsquos services was not sufficient inducement for the Democratic Unionist Party to come on board. The joke doing the rounds last week was that she tried to fall on her sword and missed.But these things have a momentum of their own, and the Tory leadership election has already begun. Boris Johnson is the narrow frontrunner, but that could change. He might win the membership, but under Tory rules the parliamentary party has to agree the two candidates put to a postal ballot. The remainers in the Tory benches might use this as an opportunity to foil the hard Brexiters by keeping Boris off the list.Of course, what should happen when a government fails to get its most important legislation through Parliament is not a leadership election, but a General Election. The government cannot govern and, even with the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, this should lead to a General Election via a vote of no confidence. Some Conservatives might prefer to fight a General Election than European elections they had promised would never take place. But events are now out of everyonersquos control.Everyone, that is, except the EU, which now holds Britainrsquos future in the balance. Itrsquos trying not to crow about Britainrsquos abject national humiliation, but the , not the UK Parliament, will now decide the UKrsquos immediate future: deal or no deal. If MPs agree this week to back a soft Brexit involving the customs union and alignment with the single market, Brussels has promised to fast-track it in a matter of days. But the alternative, a long extension, will also suit the European Union.That means more money from Britainrsquos budget contribution, and serves as a warning to other EU countries about the dangers of trying to leave the Union. It also holds out the possibility of Britain remaining in the EU,a referendum is eventually staged.Well, that remains to be seen. What is perhaps more likely is that Britain gets stuck indefinitely in a long extension. It emerged last week that the Democratic Unionist Party, which again voted against Mayrsquos withdrawal deal, could live with a long extension. Indeed, they signalled that they could live with a customs union ndash as long as it ensured no border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The DUP may be Brexiters, but they are ardent Unionists first.A soft Brexit may now be the best way of keeping the UK together. But it should be put to the people in a confirmatory vote,for no other reason than this was not what most people thought they were voting for in . MPs have the opportunity to decide this tomorrow.How and why Theresa May failed to seek the only kind of Brexit that could get through Parliament will be left for historians to judge. One of her own Cabinet ministers, quoted on BBC Newsnight, gave the provisional verdict: ldquoShersquos the sole architect of this mess because of her inability to engage in the most basic human interaction. Who says personalities donrsquot matter in great historical events

title: Marianne Taylor  Time to be more Zenlike when our Scottish banknotes are refused
story: First there was the matter of the pound price tag for two ndash TWO! ndash doughnuts. The tennis coach and mother of Wimbledon champs Andy and Jamie Murray must already have been regretting the decision not to go to Greggs for her sugar fix when she handed over her Bank of Scotland tenner only to be told by the cashier that the shop accepted only ldquoBritish notes.Read more: Judy Murrays Scottish banknote refused in London bakeryAs anyone who has read Ms Murrayrsquos excellent book outlining how she set her sons on the road to sporting greatness through sheer determination will know, Judy is not a woman who takes no for an answer. And, as her quarter of a million Twitter followers will attest, only tennis ranks above her love of cakes. So, although she didnrsquot elaborate on the outcome of the altercation, I can only imagine Ms Murray volleyed back as good as she got and ended up persuading the shop to accept Euros, groats and Monopoly money as well as Scottish cash.The tweet got so much traction because most Scots know and understand exactly how this interaction goes, just how grim and maddening it is no matter how many times yoursquove experienced it. These days many of us feel much more confident in our skins as Scots and are able to consider and reconcile our relationship with our English neighbours in more mature and expansive ways than ever before. But you still canrsquot escape the deep, primeval humiliation of having your money refused. And although this refusing is often down to ignorance rather than malice, especially in London, where so many of those who work in shops, restaurants and cafes are from overseas and donrsquot even know what a Scottish note is ndash why would they  - itrsquos something we Scots just canrsquot seem to get over. I include myself in this. Irsquove lived in London twice and looking back I used Scottish notes to symbolise and conflate the many dferent frustrations I felt with le in the metropolis.Read more: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedI could have given Basil Fawlty a run for his money as I ponticated to teenage shop assistants and foreign taxi drivers about ldquolegal tender and ldquoanti-Scottish discrimination, eventually admitting to myself that I found the ranting enjoyable, a form of stress relief, regardless of whether I succeeded in forcing my money upon them or not.Irsquom ashamed to admit now that I used to keep a Scottish tenner specically for the purpose of having a good rammy with the landlord of one of my local pubs. I suspect he enjoyed it just as much as I did, not least because hersquod never miss an opportunity to bring up the old clicheacute about Scots being tight. To give him his due, Irsquod usually get a wink and a free drink, too.The irony of all this, of course, is the fact that the banknotes so many of us defend to the end at cash desks all over England, day in, day out, are not legal tender at all. Not even in Scotland, as it turns out, where only coins have legal weight. According to the Bank of England, both coins and Bank of England notes are legal tender south of the border, with anything  a ldquomatter of agreement between the parties involved. This means each and every one of those painful refusals was legitimate, every ldquoput that in your pipe and smoke it, pal righteous speech made by you was nonsense. I found this out during my second stint in London, changing tack from rants around legality to arguments based on how petty and ldquohurtfultheir actions were. I had more luck with that.Read more: Judy Murrays Scottish banknote refused in London bakeryFormer Lib Dem Scottish Secretary Alistair Carmichael - remember him  - apprently plans to introduce a bill to the House of Commons that would oblige businesses to accept Scottish banknotes as payment. The current incumbent in the job, David Mundell, tried and failed to do something similar in .Other than the fact Parliament probably has more pressing concerns right now, surely this is simply a case of too little too late  With most of us using debit cards and contactless payments these days ndash only three in  transaction now use notes and coins, a figure expected to halve over the next decade - itrsquos clear the days of carrying banknotes of any sort are numbered: the cashless society is within swiping distance. Sweden, the first country to use the banknote back in , is expected to be the first to go completely cashless in .Read more: Why Scottish banknotes can be rejectedMaybe the time has finally come for Scots to stop fighting the good fight  Next time someone refuses your Scottish note, remain Zenlike. ldquoHow could I have been so silly  you will smile as you bring out your contactless card, resisting the urge to scream ldquoitrsquos legal tender, you ignoramus!. Not as much fun, granted, but so much better for the blood pressure.

title: 330000-scots-kids-live-in-households-on-a-financial-cliff-edge
story: Official statistics suggest , children are in households without access to pound to cover an unexpected, but necessary, expense ndash like a boiler or a fridge breaking down.Labour said the figures highlighted the thousands of families struggling with limited resources.The partyrsquos poverty spokeswoman Elaine Smith said too many of them were ldquoone big unexpected bill away from being in real financial trouble.She said: ldquoThat shows the extent of the problems in our economy, people are on their own financial clf edge.ldquoReplacing something like a fridge or boiler is expensive, but thousands of families with children would need to turn to debt to do it, because the cost of living, precarious work and stagnant wages arenrsquot letting people save for a rainy day.ldquoThe SNP has rejected Labourrsquos call to top up child benefit but families cannot afford to wait until  for the SNPrsquos income supplement. They must bring it forward.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell said: ldquoTackling ndash and ultimately eradicating ndash child poverty in Scotland is one of our main priorities.She said the Government is committed to introducing an income supplement to provide additional financial support for poorer families.She added: ldquoWe are currently exploring options to reach the greatest number of children in poverty, ensuring we top up incomes sufficiently to lt those households out of poverty.ldquoWe do this despite the UK Governmentrsquos policies that will reduce social security spend in Scotland by pound. billion by - which is pushing people into poverty.ldquoWe are investing around pound million every year to mitigate the worst of these cuts and support those on low incomes.

title: rail-review-adviser-backs-wholesale-devolution-of-network
story: Tom Harris said all lines, signals, stations and other infrastructure owned by Network Rail should be transferred to a new body answerable to Transport Scotland, which in turn reports to Scottish ministers.Mr Harris, a former Labour rail minister under Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, has previously said the management of Network Rail should be devolved. But in a speech to transport experts he went further, and said all its assets should be devolved too.It would mean responsibility for both trains and tracks coming together under the Scottish Government, allowing for more efficient, joined up decision-making.He said it would be ldquoabsurdHighways England was also responsible for motorways in Scotland, yet a single UK-wide body still owned and managed the rail lines north of the border, despite transport and Scotlandrsquos train franchises being devolved.The plan would require UK government approval and a Treasury write-off of at least the Scottish element of Network Railrsquos poundbn debt.Mr Harris is understood to have floated the idea to the Williams Rail Review, which he advises through a place on its expert challenge .Set up in September under former British Airways boss Keith Williams, the review is the most far-reaching shake-up of rail services in the UK since privatisation almost  years.When it reports this autumn, its recommendations on the structure of the industry and priorities for passengers and freight will automatically become government policy.At present, rail in Scotland is a mix of the devolved and the reserved.Transport Scotland oversees the train operating franchises, but rail infrastructure is owned and run by Network Rail, a UK-wide body under the UK Transport Secretary.This split responsibility has been highlighted by the decline in ScotRailrsquos performance, as around half of its problems are due to faults on Network Rail, not the trains.Mr Harris, a Glasgow MP from  to , said civil servants in London or at Network Railrsquos Milton Keynes base should not be making crucial decisions about rail infrastructure in Scotland.He said: ldquoI have long been of the view that the maximum amount of devolution should be applied to the management of Network Rail in Scotland.ldquoThis Rail Review gives us an opportunity to go even further.ldquoNo one believes that Highways England should have ownership or responsibility for the motorway network here in Scotland: it is owned and maintained by the Scottish Government and it would be absurd to propose any alternative structure.ldquoWe now have an opportunity to create a separate status for the railways in Scotland, with all infrastructure - the lines, the signalling and the stations - owned by an entirely separate organisation from Network Rail, just as Transport Scotland is separate from Highways England.ldquoThis would simply and speed up management decisions about our infrastructure, which should have no impact whatever on the broader GB industry and which, therefore, doesnrsquot need oversight by a GB-based body like Network Rail.Mr Harris told the Herald: ldquoMy views on the devolution of Network rail are well known. They have been in the public domain for some years. Naturally people will look at those comments and see that I have gone a step further. but itrsquos entirely up to Keith Williams and the Expert Challenge Panel whether they want to take my comments on board.The Scottish Government said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has made no secret of our repeated calls to the Secretary of State for Transport that Network Rail s should be devolved to Scottish Ministers and the Scottish Parliament, and we welcome the growing support for that position. We fund Network Rail in Scotland, set its objectives, yet lack proper influence over its operations and that must change. The UK Rail Review, under the leadership of Keith Williams, will provide an opportunity to deliver real and meaningful structural change in Scotland. We want to see a system where we can consider all options for a railway that is fully aligned to the needs and aspirations of Scotlandrsquos communities.

title: tv-review-whats-the-prognosis-on-new-medical-drama-trust-me
story: STILL waiting for thatNHSop  Reckon you wonrsquot see the inside of a ward this side of Christmas  Then think yourself lucky. Judging by the goings on in this medical drama, a body would need itshead examined to willingly enter a Scottish hospital.The last series of Trust Me featured a nurseposing as a doctor in Edinburgh. This time the location is Glasgow, and there is a killer on the ward. Glesga, Glesga, Glesga, always going too far. As Sir Sean almost says in The Untouchables, Edinburgh sends one to the hospital, you send oneto the morgue.Then again, one wonders what too far would look like in a drama that is clearly pitching its tent in medical melodrama territory. Think Rear Window with a sprinkling of Shutter Island and every other ldquoIs this happening or is he she imagining it all  offering.Whittaker promoted to doctorThe mind being messed with here, maybe, is Corporal Jamie McCain Harry Potter who arrives on the ward just in time to see a body bag being closed, which is only marginally worse than rocking up after tea and toast has finished. Jamie, shot in the back while serving abroad, must remain as immobile as possible until the shock to his system subsides and the damage can be assessed. It hardly helps with his recovery to hear from a fellow patient that the mortality rate on the ward is heading off the charts. Or that bizarre incidents, like scissors being left in beds for patients to impale themselves on, are re. ldquoI didnrsquot realise that being a cripple was so dangerous, says Jamie. Stick around, kid.Presiding over the gloomy chaos is Dr Watson - hersquos heard all the jokes - played by John Hannah. Between this gig and last weekrsquos The Victim, the Milky Bars and drinks are on the hard-working Mr Hannah, ably supported here by Ashley Jensen as a physio named Debbie Dorrell. This Debbie, lest you are wondering, does stretches, some of them with Dr Watson.As luck would have it in Dan Seftonrsquos drama, Jamie is the ideal chap to be aroundrum goings on are happening. Not only is he a former military policeman, like Lee Childrsquos Jack Reacher, but he has remarkable powers of recovery, being able to go from barely moving to making it across the ward to retrieve what could be a vital piece of evidence. Granted, he did so v-e-r-y, v-e-r-y, v-e-r-y slowly News at Ten would have to be delayed. He also fancies himself as a bit of a John Curtice, describing the chap in bed five as ldquodared to vote SNP for the first time but switched back to the Tories. Watch your back, Sir John.Susan Swarbrick meets John HannahJamie seems more than capable of looking after himself, but Watson worries there is a failure to come to terms with his injuries. ldquoI think we are still deep in a certain Egyptian river, he tells a staff meeting. Aswheeling out a joke thatrsquos as old as the pyramids was not bad enough, someone sees fit to explain it for any two-year-olds who happen to be up past their bedtime.Ashley Jensen interviewedCome the end of the first of four episodes, Jamie definitely thinks there might be more to this joint than initially met his eye. Then again, he has been told that the mind can play tricks, which is as clear a signal as any to the viewer that nothing here is as it seems. Maybe the entire Scottish NHS is an illusion and thatrsquos why you are still waiting for that op  Trust me: stranger explanations have been offered.

title: animal-charity-demands-ban-on-horrific-snares
story: The Scottish SPCA said hundreds of snares were set in Scotland every year.While many of them are legal, others are illegal or set illegally.The charity has received  calls about snares to its animal helpline since the beginning of last year, and attended  incidents involving the devices.But its special investigations unit believes the actual number of animals killed by snares could be ldquohundreds, including many unreported.The deadly devices are also indiscriminate and have been known to harm domestic pets such as dogs and cats as well as wild animals including roe deer.Mike Flynn, the Scottish SPCArsquos chief superintendent, said: ldquoThe suffering that an animal endures in a snare is horric and that is why we are in favour of an outright ban on the use of snares in Scotland.The charity also released distressing images of animals including a fox and a badger caught in snares.One Scottish SPCA undercover inspector said: ldquoWe have been alerted to multiple animals caught in snares, who have been caused an immense amount of suffering, leading to their death.ldquoSnaring is legal subject to very stringent conditions.ldquoWe see a lot of cases of illegal snaring, or legal snares being used illegally. The use of snares is very technical and time-consuming and unless a person is willing to dedicate the time and effort, itrsquos highly likely an animalrsquos welfare will be compromised.

title: emirates-a380-super-jumbo-arrives-for-start-of-new-scheduled-service-from-glasgow
story: But the thousands of spectators gathered next to Glasgow Airportrsquos perimeter fence werenrsquot about to let a dreich Tuesday evening keep them away from the historic aviation eventthey had been waiting for.And they were rewarded as the worldrsquos largest commercial passenger plane, the iconic ldquosuper-jumbo A, touched down in the city.Wersquore live watching the A land at Glasgow Airport #HelloAhttps:t.co GEhEXgwFIIThe Emirates flight EK marks the first time the double-decker craft has arrived on a scheduled passenger service, with airport bosses investing around pound million in infrastructure to ensure the airport is ready for regular trips between Glasgow and Dubai.Among the improvements is Scotlandrsquos only triple air bridge - ensuring that passengers disembark without descending to the ground.And having three arms instead of two will allow passengers to board and disembark more efficiently.As it taxied down the runway last night, a piper was on hand to greet the jet on the tarmac with a rendition of Flower of Scotland.Mark Johnston, managing director of Glasgow Airport, described it as a ldquobig day for the travel hub.He added: ldquoWe welcomed the A back in  and it was on a one-off rotation but this is the start of a scheduled daily service.ldquoWersquove invested over poundm.ldquoWersquove increased the size of the pier, wersquove made changes on the airfield.ldquoThis was a natural progression. Emirates started as a once a day service -years-ago, then went to twice a day and the aircraft size increased and now wersquove got the A.ldquoWersquove been planning this moment since it first arrived in . The project on the ground has been going on six months and our team has been fantastic.Mr Johnston added: ldquoWe knew we would get excitement but the staff and everyone around the airport has really enjoyed tonight.Standing over  metres high and with a wingspan of nearly  metres, the massive double-decker aircraft will have a three-class cabin configuration, offering  private suites in first class,  lie flat seats in business, and  seats in economy.Jon Sheppard, head of commercial at Emirates, said: ldquoWersquore very excited because today marks the first time wersquove had a scheduled A flying into Scotland.ldquoItrsquos also timely because it was fteen years last week since we launched to Glasgow to Dubai route.ldquoIt seems like timing for us to bring it here and itrsquos great news for Scotland and itrsquos a great celebration of our partnership with Glasgow Airport.ldquoIn that time wersquove carried . million passengers and beyond to  destinations.ldquoItrsquos an aircraft like no other.ldquoWe have shower spas, on flight lounge,more than a thousand channels of entertainment and wi. Wherever we take it - itrsquos well received.ldquoOur second runway in Dubai is being upgraded and we thought this would be a great time to bring the A into service in Glasgow.Although the arrival of the A yesterday marks a major new chapter in Glasgow Airportrsquos growth, the history of the aircraft itself appears to be drawing to a close.Launched in , the pound million planes were intended to carry large numbers of passengers between major international hubs, with further flights on smaller planes taking them along ldquospokes to their eventual destination.Its capacity is around  passengers and it can operate over a range of up to , nautical miles.However, the air industry is increasingly looking to use small, versatile aircraft to carry more customers directly to their destination and the A never achieved the expectations of manufacturer Airbus who had hoped to sell  of them.In fact, just  had been ordered by January of this year, with Emirates operating more than  of those, with plans for a fleet of .When its biggest customer cut that order by a quarter, the writing was on the wall and Airbus announced in February it would cease production by .

title: Rosemary Goring  New hope for Macron amid the ashes of despair
story: Fire on this scale is a haunting reminder of bombing blitzes, and not what anyone expects on a balmy springtime evening. Whether that makes the shock greater is irrelevant: the loss and sorrow are the same. The rapid response of Parisians spoke of the deep place Notre Dame holds in Francersquos psyche. ldquoIt was Parisrsquos lighthouse, said one, indicating that this marvel of medieval gothic architecture was the brightest of all beacons in the famous city of lights. ldquoIt is our history, our literature, our imagination, said President Emmanuel Macron, vowing ldquowe will rebuild Notre Dame together.All of us who have visited Paris have made a bee-line for this remarkable, forbidding place, which perhaps explains why its destruction has touched people across the world. Notre Dame, home of Victor Hugorsquos tender-hearted hunchback, Quasimodo, is to Paris what Edinburgh Castle is to the capital: a massive, seemingly immovable monument, witness to centuries of turbulent affairs. Both have represented an unchanging presence around which tides of revolutions and revolts, war and politics have washed.As it lies in partial ruin, Notre Dame is being talked of as part of Francersquos soul. Yet this -year-old building carries meaning far beyond the countryrsquos border. It was here that Napoleon Bonaparte was crowned, and Joan of Arc beatied, but it was also the scene of Henry VI of Englandrsquos coronation as King of France, when he was a child. More than a century later, on April  , , Mary Stuart was married beneath its graceful soaring roof to Francis, the dauphin, son of Henri II. By all accounts it was an eye-wateringly extravagant event. A large theatrical stage was built outside the cathedral, and inside there was a massive triumphal arch. As weddings went, it was the most spectacular Notre Dame had ever witnessed.Read more: Macron vows to rebuild cathedralI doubt therersquos a country in Europe whose history has not crossed with the cathedralrsquos at some point. In certain respects, it is the most venerable symbol of an emerging Europe, a fulcrum for events that have made the continent what it is today. No wonder crowds watching the inferno from the Icircle de la Citeacute or on television wept.The largest of its  bells, Emmanuel, shares its name with the president. This coincidence might just prove fateful. Mr Macron rushed to the scene before the fire wholly engulfed the roof and spire. It is a little ironic that, as the flames took hold, he cancelled a recorded speech due to be broadcast at eight that evening. This statement was intended to restart his first term in office, and go some way towards appeasing the gilets jaunes movement, which has badly damaged his credibility and his countryrsquos stability.Doubtless he postponed because of the gravity of the unfolding disaster. Even so, Mr Macronrsquos emotional proclamation late into the night, in which he pledged to see the cathedral restored to glory, might prove to have been a masterly stroke.It is too cynical to suggest that even as the fire blazed the president understood that this crisis could improve his standing. But the political fall-out might nevertheless work to his advantage. In a way that no prepared script could, the presidentrsquos response to the fire, and his assurance that ldquotogether the cathedral will be rebuilt, will have won him new friends and admirers. He might have misjudged the national mood when handling the gilets jaunesrsquo demands, but on the night when Notre Dame burned, he too was ablaze. Instinctively he gauged the depth of feeling this place rouses in the people he governs. That affection, and the profound heritage the cathedral represents, crosses political, ideological and class ides. The wealthy of the Bouled Saint Germain feel the same in this matter as their compatriots in downtrodden rural France.If anything could unite people across the board, it is the sight of the countryrsquos best-loved building wreathed in blood-orange smoke. Some will doubtless see this calamity as a warning or sign, as when York Minster went on fire. Certainly, the potency of the pictures of such a blaze is primitive. You cannot fail to respond, nor to feel a passing shiver of superstition that, at this exceptionally troubled and uncertain time in Europe, it holds a message of some kind.For Mr Macron, that message might simply be that Notre Dame is a symbol of what unites the nation, an olive branch of sorts. In promising without hesitation to secure its future, he was committing also to hold together the France of liberteacute, eacutegaliteacute and fraterniteacute.It might not be the speech he expected to deliver, but it mayprove to be the finest he has yet made.

title: letters-view-from-france-can-help-us-see-more-clearly
story: Mr Burleigh is clearly very annoyed that, from the useful perspective of living in Europe along with hundreds of thousands of British expats likely to be affected by Brexit and able to observe the conduct of politicians in Westminster and television news coverage of the progress of Brexit through both houses, Ms Cook has simply and clearly deplored several aspects of the situation and urged Scotland to consider a better future than what is offered there.His subsequent letter is, putting it mildly, disingenuous. He ignores the powerful propaganda effect of cutting out any evidence of SNP contribution to Brexit debates in Westminster from TV news bulletins and suggests that fairness exists in the opportunity, later, to dig around other TV channels and archives to find them. He must have missed the whipping and gerrymandering techniques employed by the Tory Party, and deplored by the Speaker himself, on several other occasions to deny opposing speakers, especially the SNP, the right to speak at all ndash especially on the Withdrawal Act itself.The irony of suggesting that Ms Cook misjudges the situation by viewing Scotland from France through ldquorose-coloured glasses while claiming that Theresa May has little or no responsibility for the horrible saga of the Withdrawal Agreement, blaming it on the civil service, lies deep. Describing that ladyrsquos behaviour as courageous rather than manically relentless as we are driven thickly towards the madness of a constitutionally illegal Meaningful Vote  next week and a last-minute European election campaignseems fancul and fantastic, rose-coloured thinking indeed.Thank goodness for Fidelma Cook. Thank goodness for the cooling effect of irony. If Westminster had not sunk so deeply into chaos under this administration andthe prospects were not so dangerous, Mr Burleigh might even have made us smile.Frances McKie, Ash Hill, Evanton, Ross-shire.I HAVE never before submitted a letter to The Herald, or any other national newspaper for that matter, but I cannot allow Archie Burleighs absurd comments to go unchallenged.In the first instance, as a retired newspaper reporterI can assure Mr Burleigh that The Herald does not employ "hacks". On the contrary, its editorial team includes some of the most talented journalists and informed columnists in the business and Fidelma Cook is no exception.Secondly, he asserts that the Prime Ministers parliamentary party is "probably the most truly representative" of the opinions of the entire country with so many isions apparent. That is, at best, a moot point, but it is those very isions within the Conservative Party that lie at the heart of the Brexit madness.Yes, there have always been Euro-sceptics within the Labour Party and there is clear evidence that some members of the SNP also voted Leave in that ill-conceived referendum. But this is primarily a Conservative Party problem and has plagued a succession of Tory Party leaders for decades. What tipped David Camerons hand and prompted him to make a mad dash to the polls was the emergence of Ukipand the threat it was beginning to pose to Tory seats. Lastly, I would say to Mr Burleigh,hes concerned about paid "hacks" offering opinions which I assume are contrary to his own, he should spare a thought for others whose attempts at rational debate are constantly undermined by the pro-Brexit bilge pumped out on a daily basis by the hacks employed on some of the English-based right-wing press.James Cuthbert,Drumellan Road,Alloway, Ayr.IM going to leap quickly in defence of the Letters Editor, obviously in the hope of currying favour, after Archie Burleighs letter today.Mr Burleigh complains that Fidelma Cook has a guaranteed place in the opinion firmament while ordinary mortals have to jump through editorial hoops to see our opinions published in the Letters Pages. I too frequently have contributions ignored, to my disappointment, but its usually clear that the topic has moved on or that others have said it better.However, as for Mr Burleighs suggestion that Ms Cook, domiciled in France, sees Scotlands position in Europe through rose-tinted glasses au contraire, as Fidelma might say. I suggest that from a distance the Brexit farce, and its threat to Scotlands economy, is only too painfully clear.Mr Burleigh quotes Harry S Truman, "progress occurs when courageous skilful leaders seize the opportunity to change things for the better". Quite so, but what happens when stubborn, purblind and ham-fisted leaders are in control John Jamieson, Craigie Road, Ayr.Read more: The UK is damned whatever is to come. But Scotland isnrsquotAS a long-time reader and admirer of Fidelma Cooks column in the Herald Magazine on Saturdays, it has now been pointed out to me by Archie Burleigh that Fidelma is a "paid hack", living in France, whose column sullies the Magazines pages by expressing political opinions with which he disagrees. Perhaps Mr Burleigh will enlighten us by explaining the dference between a paid hack living in France and a well-respected professional journalist living in the European Union. I would suggest that to qualy for the latter characterisation it would be necessary for the paid hack to express views in line with those of Mr Burleigh.Willie Maclean, Braehead Avenue, Milngavie.THE agreement between the European Union and the UK to extend Article  until the end of October has rightly been welcomed by business leaders across theand breadth of these islands. This was the right decision, as leaving without a deal this spring would have put businesses, local economies and livelihoods at risk.But the value of this extension will only be realised when political consensus is reached about a sensible way forward. Decision-makers cannot waste the time that the country has been afforded. In addition, we must start to address fundamental issues about the direction of our economy.For firms north of the Border, there are few more important issues than the development of an immigration system that meets Scotlandrsquos needs. Outlined proposals must be changed to avoid putting Scottish businesses at risk and undermining efforts to develop demographically sustainable communities in many areas. Developing a more flexible, responsive, forward-looking system should be a priority for policymakers.Andrew McRae,Scotland Policy Chair, Federation of Small Businesses, Berkeley Street, Glasgow.

title: iain-macwhirter-the-burning-issue-has-to-be-the-need-to-abandon-coal
story: Unlike Brexit, Scottish independence or even CND, climate change just doesnrsquot provoke fierce public emotions any more. Indeed, the problem for environmentalists, in the West at least, is perhaps that theyrsquove been too successful. The science of climate change is now more or less universally accepted, since the BBC started banning climate-change deniers like Lord Lawson from the Today programme. If everyone more or less agrees, therersquos no controversy.Civil disobedience, and stunts like superglueing naked bottoms to the safety glass in the House of Commons, at least gets attention. Politicians insist that they are listening . The UK is, perhaps surprisingly, one of the world leaders in CO reduction, and emissions are now lower than in Victorian times. The Scottish Government is committed to net  per cent elimination of greenhouse gases by , and has exceeded its emissions targets since it began the process of decarbonisation a decade ago. Admittedly, this is largely down to the closure of coal-fired power stations, like Longannet, and there remain problems with home heating and transport.:Extinction Rebellion protests: The activists who plan further disruption in Scotland to prevent environmental destructionThe electrication of vehicles is moving forward ndash though much too slowly because of the lack of charging points across Scotland. But it is happening. Petrol and diesel cars are to be phased out after . In fact, the internal combustion engine may become obsolete in towns some time before that, so rapid is the development of electric vehicles, especially micro-transportation like electric scooters and e-bikes. Buses and lorries, though, are another matter, and diesels are defended by powerful economic interests like the road hauliers and distribution companies like Amazon.Climate protesters like thecolumnist George Monbiot insist that we must ldquooverthrow capitalism to save the planet. But technology is turning the market green at a remarkable rate. The cost of renewable energy has fallen faster than anyone could have imagined  years ago. According to the investor bible, Forbes, solar and wind energy is about to make coal, gas and even nuclear power obsolete in the West in the next couple of years. It says three-quarters of US coal-fired power stations are already uneconomic, despite Donald Trumprsquos promotion of coal. Therersquos even talk of imminent estment in loss-making fossil fuel stocks causing a global financial ldquocorrection or stock market crash.Read more: Climate protestors block Edinburgh streetHowever, the Extinction Rebellion protesters are right to warn against complacency. The battle against climate change is far from over. President Trump disgraced America by withdrawing from the Paris Climate agreement. But the US is not the worldrsquos worst polluter. The inconvenient truth, as Al Gore might put it, is that protests against climate chaos are futilecountries like China continue to open a coal-powered station nearly every week.There has been much dispute about this claim, which environmentalists say is a racist myth designed to sht the blame for climate change to a developing country. However, there is no doubt that the second-largest economy in the world is also the biggest single polluter. China is responsible for one-third of global CO emissions, and thatrsquos largely down to its anachronistic dependence on burning coal.One of the greatest obstacles in the way of meeting  Paris climate target of capping global warming to two per cent above pre-industrial levels , is the persistent use of coal, largely in south-east Asia. China currently consumes half the worldrsquos coal and has increased coal-powered capacity by  per cent since , according to the International Energy Agency .True, China is also emerging as a world leader in renewable energy and is opening huge solar farms by the week. But promises by the communist government to curb coal use have not been honoured. According to the Global Energy Monitor, China is in the process of adding  gigawatts of coal-fired power, equivalent to the entire capacity of US coal. Hence the claim that it is opening a coal plant every week.The IEA say that to meet the UN targets, China would have to close all its coal-fired power stations within the next  years. That isnrsquot going to happen. Indeed, according to the German environment and human rights NGO, Urgewald, China is busy exporting coal-fired power stations to at least  countries, from Kenya to the Balkans. In Serbia, Chinese companies are building the countryrsquos first coal-fired power plant in  years.And itrsquos not just China. The IEA estimate that Asia as a whole is becoming coal central, with hundreds of coal power stations in the pipeline. Indonesia and Vietnam are turning to coal as are Bangladesh, and with Chinese help, the Philippines. Japan has ed to burning more coal following the disaster at Fukushima nuclear plant in . Without the active involvement of these countries, then the efforts of countries like the UK will be in vain. And of course in communist countries like China, climate protesters would be in jail, not on the streets campaigning.Developing countries have a strong case for special treatment. They can legitimately claim that the current warmth of the planet is not their fault. China has only become an industrialised nation in the last  years, whereas we in the West have been pumping C into the atmosphere since the start of the industrial revolution  years ago. Living standards are poor for the vast majority of ordinary Chinese families, who consume only a fraction of the goods and services we enjoy in the UK. Chinese citizens, therefore, have a much smaller carbon footprint.These are strong arguments and are recognised by the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change. Despite Americarsquos objections, there may have to be resource transfers to developing nations,they are to curb their uneconomic coal use. This is a global problem demanding global action and time is running out. In a very real sense, we are all in this together.

title: owner-rapped-by-watchdog-over-raffle-to-get-rid-of-scots-castle
story: Susan DeVere set up the contest after her attempts to sell Orchardton Castle, near Auchencairn, Kirkcudbrightshire, failed.Built in the s, the -bedroom property had been valued at between pound. million and pound. million and comes with five acres of land and views across the Solway Firth.Tickets for the raffle, launched on Facebook and the winacastle website, cost pound and the winner was promised the opportunity to "win the whole building freehold".However the raffle failed to generate enough ticket sales and the prize was changed to cash giveaways of pound,, pound, and pound,, which were handed out in June last year.One person complained to the Advertising Standards Authoritythat the raffle had been administered unfairly because the prize had been changed to a cash amount.Mrs DeVere told the ASA that all property competitions were run in the same way and that the castle could not be awardedthere were not enough entries received to clear the mortgage.She said it was made clear from the beginning thatnot enough entries were received, the property would not be awarded and a cash prize would be offered instead.Mrs DeVere added that after the prize draw had taken place the winner was offered a share of the property and a chance to run a business there had they wanted to, which was a goodwill offer unconnected to the competition. The winner chose to accept the cash prize.The ASA said the complainant had entered the promotion in the hope of winning the castle."However, we considered that a share of the property or any cash alternative that was less than the value of the property, were not reasonable equivalents to the prize as advertised."Because neither the advertised prize nor a reasonable alternative had been awarded, we concluded that the promotion had not been administered fairly and was in breach of the code."Mrs DeVere said in a statement: "It is fair enough to challenge a competition or any unfairness and it should have taken the ASA a heartbeat to look at our site and see that from the beginning everything was spelled out, including that a cash prize to the value of tickets . Examples were givenwould happenenough entries were not received."She said she intends to appeal the ruling.She later added: "In the many interviews and that I did during that time, I said every time thatwe dont get enough entries, it is to be a cash prize."We raised over pound, for the charities and we gave the rest of the money away."Mrs Devere said at the time that she hopedto sell , of the raffle tickets and saidthe castle could be lived in, rented out, sold or made into a business.And she saidshe would donate any extra cash raised to charities including the Rainbow Trust Childrenrsquos Charity and ones trying to stop the Yulin dog meat festival in China.The castle, which is thought to have been built by smuggler William Douglas Robinson in  has seen le as a hotel, a school and a hospital for wounded soldiers.

title: nicola-sturgeon-damaging-impact-of-brexit-cannot-be-fully-mitigated
story: The First Minister will speak at the STUC conference in Dundee on Wednesday and is expected to warn that any form of Brexit wouldharm living standards and risk jobs.:Nicola Sturgeon: Scotland should be a driving force within the EUAn extension to Article  was granted earlier this month, meaning that the UK will not leave the European Union until October  unless a deal can be agreed in Parliament sooner.It is a relief that ndash thanks to the patience of the EU ndash we will not be crashing out tomorrow. But the UK must not waste this time ndash allowing people to decidethey still want to leave is now imperative. And Scotlandrsquos interests must be protected.mdash Nicola SturgeonApril , Ms Sturgeon is expected to say: ldquoThe EUrsquos decision to offer a further six month extension is hugely welcome.ldquoHowever, it places a duty on the UK Government to use this time better than it has used the previous three years.ldquoIn particular, it must drop the damaging red lines that have done so much to cause this mess. Instead, it must talk seriously ndash with all opposition parties and devolved governments ndash about what our long-term relationship with Europe could reasonably look like.ldquoIn addition, it should recognise a fact that has become more and more obvious in recent months, and is gaining increasing support.ldquoAny deal that is arrived at is likely to be very dferent from what many voters thought they were promised. It should therefore be put to the people again. A second referendum is now the best way of resolving Brexit.ldquoMy hope ndash although this is in no way guaranteed ndash is that in a second referendum, the UK as a whole would opt to remain.ldquoThere are many reasons for that. One of them is that any form of Brexit ndash no matter how soft ndash will have damaging consequences for peoplersquos jobs, living standards and opportunities.:Nicola Sturgeon to outline Indyref plans within daysldquoThose consequences can be partially mitigated ndash but they cannot be prevented, and no-one should pretend that they can.The First Minister will also say that workersrsquo rights cannot be guaranteed after Brexit, despite assurances from the UK Government.Ms Sturgeon will say: ldquoThe UK Government has said that it wonrsquot use Brexit to reduce workersrsquo rights ndash but when it comes to workersrsquo rights, I wouldnrsquot trust the Tories as far as I could throw them.ldquoSome MPs have been open about wanting to slash regulation. The Tory approach would be disastrous. It would damage the health, welfare and security of workers ndash and it would harm the productivity of the economy as a whole.ldquoIt would also be anathema to the vision for Scotland which all of us share.

title: new-call-for-public-inquiry-into-north-sea-helicopter-safety
story: Their move through an emergency motion at the STUC conference comes after  people have died in the past decasde in incidents involving Super Puma helicopters in UK and Norwegian sectors of the North Sea.The union said such an inquiry is essential due to the "ongoing decline in offshore workers confidence" in the safety of offshore helicopter operations.Fourteen oil workers and two crew died when a Bond Super Puma plunged into the water off the Aberdeenshire coast on April  .An Air Accidents Investigation Branchprobe into the crash found that the aircraft suffered a "catastrophic failure" of its main rotor gearbox, while a fatal accident inquiryin  found that the tragedy might have been avoided.A Super Puma EC helicopter which ditched off Fair Isle in The disaster has already led toa long ban on Super Puma aircraft off Scotlandrsquos shores and a detailed technical investigation.Last monthtwo opposition MSPs,Labourrsquos Lewis Macdonald and Liberal Democrat Tavish Scott, renewed demands for such an inqui:Inquiry calls as Scotland marks decade since Super Puma tragedyNow in an emergency motion tabled at the conference in Dundee on Wednesday, the RMT said that the FAI process does not offer "meaningful safety lessons for the wider industry" and is not an effective means of restorative justice for the families affected by offshore helicopter incidents.RMT general secretary, Mick Cash said: "It is nothing short of a scandal that the Scottish and UK Governments are opposing the public inquiry that is clearly needed to tackle the decline we have seen over the last  years in offshore workers confidence in the safety of the helicopter transport they are required to travel in."That is why are calling for renewed support from across the Scottish trade union movement for our on-going campaign in Dundee today."Both RMT and Unite support an inquiry, which would cover commercial pressures brought on operators by oil and gas companies and we now have a signicant body of cross-party support, including SNP MPs in Westminster, who have added their voices to this important campaign for a just response to the deaths, trauma and growing safety fears of North Sea oil and gas workers and their families."Eleven passengers and two crew members were killed when a Super Puma  aircraft came down near the city of Bergen, Norway, in April  while in August  a Super Puma L carrying oil rig workers ditched in the North Sea leaving four people dead.In a statement after the FAI Bond Offshore said it accepted that it had made mistakes and that lessons have been learned and continue to be learned.The motion, moved by Aberdeen Trades Union Council, calls on the STUC congress to write to the Scottish Government urging them to back a full independent public inquiry.Eleven passengers and two crew members were killed when a Super Puma  aircraft came down near the city of Bergen, Norway, in April  while in August  a Super Puma L carrying oil rig workers ditched in the North Sea leaving four people dead.The crash in  claimed the lives of captain and co-pilot Paul Burnham, , from Methlick in Aberdeenshire, and Mr Menzies, who was from Worcestershire.Five men fromAberdeendied: Alex Dallas, , James Costello, , Stuart Wood, , Vernon Elrick, , and Brian Barkley,  and two workers were from Aberdeenshire: Leslie Taylor, , from Kintore, and Warren Mitchell, , from Oldmeldrum.The other victims were Raymond Doyle, , from Cumbernauld David Rae, , from Dumfries Gareth Hughes, , from Angus Nairn Ferrier, , fromDundee James Edwards, , from Liverpool Nolan Goble, , from Norwich and Mihails Zuravskis, , from Latvia.In a statement after the FAI, the helicopter operator, Bond Offshore, said it accepted that it had made mistakes and that lessons have been learned and continue to be learned.

title: further-38m-invested-in-work-to-tackle-fuel-poverty-in-scotland
story: Last year, a target was set that no more than % of households in Scotland would be in fuel poverty by .The funding was awarded by Warmer Homes Scotland, a Government scheme designed to help people in need make their homes warmer and more comfortable by installing energy saving measures.On a visit to Dundee to meet the ,th Warmer Homes customer, housing minister Kevin Stewart said the investment, and the extension of Warmer Homes Scotland to , demonstrates the Governments commitment to eradicating fuel poverty and increasing energy efficiency.Mr Stewart said: "I welcome the contract extension with Warmworks to continue our work to eradicate fuel poverty. title: church-of-scotland-urges-bellringing-support-for-notre-dame
story: Rt Rev Susan Brown, Moderator of the General Assembly, in the wake of thedevastating fire that ravaged Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris on Monday.She is encouraging churches and cathedrals, where possible, to ring their bells at pm tomorrow, which is roughly the same time as the fire broke out at the -year-old Gothic building.Most of the roof was destroyed, causing the steeple to collapse, but French President Emmanuel Macron has promised that Notre-Dame will be rebuilt within five years.Donations to fund the work at the Unesco World Heritage site have already reached pound million.:Notre Dame Cathedral Paris: A historyMrs Brown said: ldquoThe world has been shocked and saddened by the devastating fire at Notre Dame Cathedral.ldquoThe reaction is so great because the Church is more than just a building.ldquoMany buildings, as well as being worship spaces, are a celebration of the gts of stone masons, carpenters, glass makers, artists and musicians.ldquoThey also house history and Notre Dame is one such church.ldquoIn sympathy and solidarity with the people of Paris, I would encourage our churches and cathedrals, where possible, to ring their bells at pm on Thursday for seven minutes.Rev Jan Steyn, minister of the Scots Kirk in Paris, said Notre Dame was a place of awe, mystery and majesty and the disaster has had a profound impact on people.ldquoIt is not only a presence for the Parisians, it belongs to the world, he added.ldquoOn the night of the fire, we all went to bed with a sense of loss.ldquoSomething we have taken for granted for centuries, or at least for as long as we remember, seemed to be disappearing right in front of us.ldquoNotre Dame is a tourist attraction, a place of worship, a refuge, a character in movies and novels.ldquoBut for millions of people it is an icon, a home, a place with personality.ldquoFor Parisians, Notre Dame is a calming presence and a reminder of the bigger presence.ldquoIt is a place revered by a nation even though France is a secular state.Mr Steyn said Notre Dame Cathedral represented a common Christian heritage, retelling the story of God and of Christ.He said the banks of the River Seine were lined by thousands of onlookers as the flames ripped through the top half of the cathedral.ldquoThey stood mostly in silence, fists clenched covering their lips, he recalled.ldquoThe unthinkable, the unspeakable is happening. ldquo Mr Steyn said he was very moved by the sight of young French people singing psalms which was a demonstration of hope and faith.ldquoOn Tuesday, we woke up with better news than expected, he added.ldquoMany treasures were saved, the organ, although damaged, did survive and the basic structure seems to be in better shape than we thought.ldquoThe fire in the Notre Dame made us aware of how vulnerable we are, how vulnerable our treasures, monuments and our world are.Second World Hero Rev Dr Donald Caskie was the minister at the Scots Kirk between - and -.He set up safe houses in the south of France and helped more than , trapped allied service personnel escape the Nazis.The International Presbytery of the Church of Scotland has  congregations,  of which are on the European continent.

title: snp-msps-say-sturgeon-out-of-step-on-trans-rights
story: Three prominent female MSPs - a current minister, a former minister and a committee convener - appeared to suggest the First Minister was too uncritical on trans issues.They also suggested the SNPrsquos Holyrood group had discussed the subject and most of its MSPs felt as they did, and they had expected that message to be passed to Ms Sturgeon.:SNP equalities chief in row over trans rights commentsThe trio includes Ruth Maguire, the convener of Holyroodrsquos equalities committee, who wrote FFS, short for ldquofor f***rsquos sake in response to some pro-trans praise of Ms Sturgeon.The leak prompted a backlash from trans rights supporters within the SNP.The party did not deny the authenticity of the leak, and said it supported trans rights.The Pink Saltire website reported the leak had come from a former worker for an MSP.The leaked messages, dated February , were prompted by Ms Sturgeon defending trans rights while on a visit to the United Nations in New York.Defending her governmentrsquos support for transgender rights, Ms Sturgeon rejected the idea that greater rights for transgender women eroded the rights of other women.She said: ldquoAs an ardent, passionate feminist, and have been all my le, I donrsquot see the greater recognition of transgender rights as a threat to me as a woman or to my feminism.Emma Rich, director of the Scottish feminist organisation Engender then tweeted in support of the First Minister, writing: ldquoSo glad to hear @NicolaSturgeon powerfully articulate this positive feminist analysis of trans rights.:Iain Macwhirter: Transgender rights  Great. But dont tell women what makes a woman: they were born that wayldquoI have huge faith in feminist Scotland to create consensus. And a nation where *all* women  girls have equal access to safety, resources,  power.Ms Maguire then shared Ms Richrsquos tweet with other MSPs and added the comment: ldquoFFS.MSP Gillian Martin, who was forced to quit as a minister after a day last year after being accused of writing transphobic comments on an old blog, replied: ldquoYup - saw it. FM a bit of step [sic] with feelings of her group.Ms Maguire replied: ldquoIndeed.Community safety minister Ash Denham then said: ldquoShe might be out of step because no one has conveyed group feelings to her Ms Maguire said: ldquoSurely SA wouldnrsquot just have ignored what everyone said This appears to be a reference to social security secretary Shirley-Anne Somerville.Deeply concerning to see this conversation between SNP elected members claiming the FM is out of step for backing trans rights in Scotland. @theSNP and @NicolaSturgeon must act pic FrZnFmpaMlThe leak messages prompted a call from LibDem MSP Alex Cole-Hamilton, the vice-convener of Holyroodrsquos equalities committee, to Ms Maguire.He tweeted: ldquoAs vice-convener of Equalities and HR committee I think urgent clarication is required from our convener, @RBFMaguire as regards her position on this matter.ldquoOur committee cannot exclude any protected group in its struggle to push for equality.:Nicola Sturgeon at STUC: "Diversity is not a weakness - it is a strength to be celebrated"The leak, on Tuesday night, also seemed to create friction between the SNPrsquos groups at Holyrood and Westminster.Three of the partyrsquos younger generation, Mhairi Black, Stewart McDonald and Angela Crawley, posted the same ldquoTrans Ally picture of pink, white and blue heart.The Scottish Trans Alliance thanked the three for ldquotweeting as trans allies. They are supporting @theSNPrsquos clear commitment to trans equality, which includes their Holyrood manesto commitment to bring gender recognition law up to international best practice.The SNP students group also issued a statement in support of trans rights.At SNP students, we have one simple belief. Trans rights are human rights. No s, no buts. #TransAlly pic qEnXWtfrIn recent weeks, SNP MSP Joan McAlpine has accused trans rights, supporters of bullying people who do not agree with them, saying they try to shut people up ldquoby labelling you and bothering you, by using extremist language.Ms McAlpine was deluged with online abuse after the committee she chairs rejected plans to change the sex question in the next census to include a third option of non-binary.The committee said the question should remain binary - male or female - with a voluntary question on gender identication, on the basis that sex and gender are distinct.The Pink Saltire quoted the former member of SNP staff saying: ldquoI was surprised to see the conversation. I really dont like the way people in the SNP have been talking about transgender people or what Joan McAlpine has been saying.ldquoOver the last few months, itrsquos seemed like more people held these views.ldquoSome people just donrsquot see whatrsquos really important ndash that trans people are possibly the most marginalised group in society right now and the suicide rates alone should surely point to the fact we must do better. I think as a party we need to get up to speed pretty fast on what is a really big deficit inequality for trans people.An SNP spokesperson said: ldquoThe SNP supports trans rights and womenrsquos rights as part of our firm commitment to human rights and equality. Trans people must be able to live their lives without facing unnecessary barriers and discrimination. It is important that any discussion on trans rights and womenrsquos rights is conducted respectfully.

title: brussels-vacancy-opens-up-as-snp-mep-retires
story: Ian Hudghton, , who has served in Brussels since November , said he was looking forward to a long-planned retirement - and possibly fighting an independence referendum.His departure means only one of the SNPrsquos two MEPs, Alyn Smith, will put himself forward as a candidate , as expected, the elections are held on May .The party must now find five other potential candidates - three women and two men - to make up its six-person regional list.They will be ranked by delegates to this monthrsquos SNP conference, with only the first two expected to be elected, with the third placed candidate having a fighting chance.Former environment minister Aileen MacLeod, former MP Margaret Ferrier and Mr Smithrsquos chief of staff Laura Rayner have expressed an interest in standing.The only female SNP MEP to date is Winnie Ewing, who served between  and .Mr Hudghtonrsquos exitfollows a row about men dominating the EU poll for the SNP.Although gender-balanced, the SNP list is not ldquozipped, meaning men and women ordered alternately, and Mr Hudghton and Mr Smith had been expected to secure the top two slots.Nicola Sturgeon said: ldquoIan Hudghton has championed Scotlands cause in the European Parliament for over  years, I am sorry to see him go.ldquoIan has been a passionate advocate for what the EU is and does for Scotland, and proved himself a first-class parliamentarian. I wish him every success in the future.In a letter to the SNPrsquos ruling body, Mr Hudghton said: ldquoAfter a great deal of thought, I have decided that I do not wish my name to be included in the selection process for SNP candidates for the European Parliamentary Elections, possibly being held in May.ldquoDuring the past couple of years, with Brexit looming, the prospect of retirement from my MEP role has become an active consideration.ldquoI look forward to having more time available for family and home.ldquoThe current five year term of the European Parliament will end on st July and I will remain a Member until that date, unless an earlier date for Brexit is agreed.He went on: ldquoI did not join the SNP as a career plan, but it has been an immense privilege to represent the SNP in the EP for more than  very eventful years.ldquoI am certain that Scotland is now closer to Independence than ever.ldquoTo be sure of winning the next referendum on Independence we will have to maximise the number of Independence conversations we have on the doorsteps with voters in every community.ldquoI look forward to participating in the ongoing campaign to build and solidy the support and momentum that we will need to win the next referendum on Independence, whenever it is held.Mr Hudghton joined the SNP in , served as an Angus councillor in the s and s.He has been SNP president since , a role previously held by Mrs Ewing.

title: off-the-plot-beechgroves-hardy-perennial-jim-mccoll-retires-at-83
story: But, aged , the Beechgrove Garden host has finally admitted it is time for him to lose the plot.BBC Scotland has announced his oh-so-very reluctant retirement from the show he has presented since . Why  His fingers are still green, but they are not so strong.Mr McColl explained: ldquoIt is time I retired, not because I have lost any interest in gardening or my enthusiasm for gardening, but just because getting old. Irsquoll be  next birthday ndash so things are going wronghellipldquoIn the sense thatI get down on my knees, Irsquom not sure I can get back up again. I have to have something to lean on.ldquoMost importantly, I have a neuropathy thing with my hands. I have no power in my fingers. I have no grip. It has just been gradually getting worse.Mr McColl is getting treatment to help with the condition, but has dficulties and is unable to do things like button his top shirt button.Gardening colleagues watching the show in previous series have also remarked to him that he has been holding gardening tools awkwardly.He said: ldquoOne of the things you want to do when you are showing off on telly, is you want to do it properly.Mr McColl formally bows out on a show to be broadcast tonight. Beechgrove, he tells co-presenter Carole Baxter ldquois half my le.I just want to grow old in privatehellipbut Irsquoll still garden.Mr McColl, from Ayrshire, has been at the helm of The Beechgrove Garden since it began in the late s from the grounds of BBC Scotlandrsquos Aberdeen base. Back then he presented alongside George Barron.Over the years he has lost count of the number of times he has said ldquoWelcome to Beechgrove Garden and his catchphrase ldquoEvery dayrsquos a school day is familiar to viewers.Beechgrove producer Gwyneth Hardy said: ldquoItrsquos the end of an era for Jim to be handing over the trowel. Itrsquos been a big decision, not taken lightly for Jim as he is genuinely passionate about communicating his knowledge of gardening.ldquoHe said to me recently that, gardening is like breathing for him itrsquos an everyday activity. I have worked with Jim for over  years and it has been a genuine privilege and an honour to work with a real Scottish cultural icon, who doesnrsquot see himself in that way, Jim thinks therersquos nothing unusual in what he does.ldquoThis makes Jim pretty unique, he has no ego, what you see is what you get and the audience love him for it. That said, even cultural icons have to retire sometime and as Jim will be  at next birthday then itrsquos not unreasonable that hersquos thinking of no longer being on our screens. He really has given half a letime of service to Beechgrove and our loyal viewers. ldquoTonightrsquos episode will include a look back at Mr McCollrsquos career on the series.Beechgrove regular Chris Beardshaw will be on screen later as will another newcomer, Aberdeenshire-based market farmer, Rosa Bevan.Ms Baxter, who has worked alongside Jim for  years, said: ldquoI am going to miss Jim after working with him for all these years but this is an appropriate time to celebrate his career. He is a great gardener and presenter. He shares his wealth of gardening knowledge in a way which engages people at all levels of gardening expertise from none to the professionals.Donalda MacKinnon, director of BBC Scotland, said: ldquoMany thousands of gardeners have been inspired and coached by Jim via The Beechgrove Garden over many years and on behalf of them all, and also for other viewers who simply love him for his knowledge and warmth, Irsquod like to thank him.Mr McCollrsquos le and achievements were celebrated in a BBC Scotland documentary called Jim McColl At  in . The programme will be shown again on Easter Monday.Last week another leading BBC figure, news presenter Jackie Bird, stepped down from presenting Reporting Scotland.

title: why-the-european-parliament-is-no-easy-ride-for-politicians
story: There is a problem with the legend. It is not true. It is not MEPs who are lazy: it is the Commentariat.Other politicians, journalists, the chattering classes, especially in the UK, all ignored the work being done by the European Parliament. The result  Nobody reported on Brussels and Strasbourg. So far too many people mistakenly thought this news black hole meant there was nothing worth reporting.In reality, the  or so MEPs do an astonishingly important job in keeping the European Commission, the blocrsquos executive, and its multi-billion-pound budget in check.Critics of the EU like to talk about unelected bureaucrats running the show  Well, like the governments of Britain and other member states, the Commission, in fact, have to get elected by parliamentarians. True, the president of the Commission is nominated by the EU Council, the body that represents those _governments of member states. But MEPs get the final say. And they can throw out the entire commission.MEPs have to approve EU laws Parliament is in charge of finessing the rule book of the single common market, to which Britain and all the other countries have signed up to ensure trade is free and fair. This involves incredibly complex areas of law on issues like the environment or fishing. These are things that count. And they affect almost all of us.Parliamentary debate in the EU is far from always firey. But this is not the yaboo of domestic politics. There are few points to be made by being aggressive. With  nations and scores of parties, MEPs need to learn to legislate by making unlikely friends. Consensus can be hard work.Some MEPs really do live up to the stereotype. UKIPrsquos , for example, at one point attended fewer than a third of votes debates and committees, being branded the laziest in Brussels. Nigel Farage famously said he did not want to ldquogo native, to engage with the whole process. ldquoI think Irsquom entitled at lunchtime to a pint, he said.

title: a96 project to consider impact of new awpr
story: Two north east politicians have highlighted the need for the A dualling process to take into account the impact of the Aberdeen Western Peripheral Route.Current infrastructure plans for dualling the A past Inverurie to Huntly are in place, and a selection of route options are being analysed.During During Portfolio Questions at Holyrood on Thursday, April , Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin requested information on how the impact of the AWPR and the projected impact of dualling the railway line between Inverurie and Dyce, as well as the building of a new station at Kintore, is being analysed and taken into account as part of this process.Commenting, Gillian Martin MSP said: “The feedback on the AWPR to date has been extremely promising and I’m glad to hear that its impact, as well as that of other infrastructure projects in the area, will be taken into account as part of the design for the A dualling programme.“The dualling of the A is one of the next phases in transforming our infrastructure and it’s great to see increasing SNP investment in the North-East.“This is a long-awaited project which promises huge potential for the region and I look forward to its continuing development.”Meanwhile north east MSP Lewis Macdonald called on ministers to reconsider the shortlisted route options for dualling the A at Inverurie, to take into account up-to-date traffic data.Following a period of settling down of traffic behaviour, a traffic data collection exercise will be undertaken by Transport Scotland and a comparison made between the forecast and actual performance of the project.The Online Inverurie or OLI option for dualling the existing A on the edge of the town was ruled out by Transport Scotland last year.Lewis Macdonald, speaking after quizzing Transport Secretary Michael Matheson at Holyrood, said: “Taking the Online Inverurie option off the table at this early stage is not only premature, but it is based on data which is seriously out of date.“I met Michael Matheson last month, to argue that Online Inverurie should be on the shortlist of possible ways of upgrading the A.
